posts.content:
"⚠️ Critical RCE Alert: 3,000 Apache ActiveMQ Servers at Risk! ⚠️"

Over 3,000 Apache ActiveMQ servers are exposed online, vulnerable to a
critical RCE flaw (CVE-2023-46604, CVSS v3: 10.0). Immediate patching is urged
to prevent potential data theft and network compromise. Stay vigilant! 🛡️💻

Apache ActiveMQ is an open-source message broker for secure communication
between clients and servers, supporting Java and various cross-language
clients and protocols like AMQP, MQTT, OpenWire, and STOMP.

The flaw in question is CVE-2023-46604, a critical severity (CVSS v3 score:
10.0) RCE that allows attackers to execute arbitrary shell commands by
exploiting class types in the OpenWire protocol.

According to Apache's disclosure on October 27, 2023, this vulnerability
affects the following Apache ActiveMQ and Legacy OpenWire Module versions:

  * Versions before 5.18.3 in the 5.18.x series
  * Versions before 5.17.6 in the 5.17.x series
  * Versions before 5.16.7 in the 5.16.x series
  * All versions before 5.15.16

To address this issue, fixes have been released in versions 5.15.16, 5.16.7,
5.17.6, and 5.18.3. It's recommended to upgrade to one of these versions to
enhance your IT security.

Tags: [#CyberSecurity](https://infosec.exchange/tags/CyberSecurity)
[#RCE](https://infosec.exchange/tags/RCE)

posts.content:
[@BleepingComputer](https://infosec.exchange/@BleepingComputer) CVE-2023-46604
(CVSS: 10.0 critical severity, disclosed 26 October 2023 by Apache)  
Apache ActiveMQ is vulnerable to Remote Code Execution.The vulnerability may
allow a remote attacker with network access to a broker to run arbitrary shell
commands by manipulating serialized class types in the OpenWire protocol to
cause the broker to instantiate any class on the classpath. Users are
recommended to upgrade to version 5.15.16, 5.16.7, 5.17.6, or 5.18.3, which
fixes this issue.

The Netherlands' National Cyber Security Centrum (NCSC) states that Proof of
Concept has been published publicly, and that they received a report from a
trusted partner that the vulnerability has been actively and specifically
exploited.
[https://advisories.ncsc.nl/advisory?id=NCSC-2023-0561](https://advisories.ncsc.nl/advisory?id=NCSC-2023-0561)

posts.content:
"⚠️ Critical RCE Alert: 3,000 Apache ActiveMQ Servers at Risk! ⚠️"

Over 3,000 Apache ActiveMQ servers are exposed online, vulnerable to a
critical RCE flaw (CVE-2023-46604, CVSS v3: 10.0). Immediate patching is urged
to prevent potential data theft and network compromise. Stay vigilant! 🛡️💻

Apache ActiveMQ is an open-source message broker for secure communication
between clients and servers, supporting Java and various cross-language
clients and protocols like AMQP, MQTT, OpenWire, and STOMP.

The flaw in question is CVE-2023-46604, a critical severity (CVSS v3 score:
10.0) RCE that allows attackers to execute arbitrary shell commands by
exploiting class types in the OpenWire protocol.

According to Apache's disclosure on October 27, 2023, this vulnerability
affects the following Apache ActiveMQ and Legacy OpenWire Module versions:

  * Versions before 5.18.3 in the 5.18.x series
  * Versions before 5.17.6 in the 5.17.x series
  * Versions before 5.16.7 in the 5.16.x series
  * All versions before 5.15.16

To address this issue, fixes have been released in versions 5.15.16, 5.16.7,
5.17.6, and 5.18.3. It's recommended to upgrade to one of these versions to
enhance your IT security.

posts.content:
[@BleepingComputer](https://infosec.exchange/@BleepingComputer) CVE-2023-46604
(CVSS: 10.0 critical severity, disclosed 26 October 2023 by Apache)  
Apache ActiveMQ is vulnerable to Remote Code Execution.The vulnerability may
allow a remote attacker with network access to a broker to run arbitrary shell
commands by manipulating serialized class types in the OpenWire protocol to
cause the broker to instantiate any class on the classpath. Users are
recommended to upgrade to version 5.15.16, 5.16.7, 5.17.6, or 5.18.3, which
fixes this issue.

The Netherlands' National Cyber Security Centrum (NCSC) states that Proof of
Concept has been published publicly, and that they received a report from a
trusted partner that the vulnerability has been actively and specifically
exploited.
[https://advisories.ncsc.nl/advisory?id=NCSC-2023-0561](https://advisories.ncsc.nl/advisory?id=NCSC-2023-0561)

posts.content:
"⚠️ Critical RCE Alert: 3,000 Apache ActiveMQ Servers at Risk! ⚠️"

Over 3,000 Apache ActiveMQ servers are exposed online, vulnerable to a
critical RCE flaw (CVE-2023-46604, CVSS v3: 10.0). Immediate patching is urged
to prevent potential data theft and network compromise. Stay vigilant! 🛡️💻

Apache ActiveMQ is an open-source message broker for secure communication
between clients and servers, supporting Java and various cross-language
clients and protocols like AMQP, MQTT, OpenWire, and STOMP.

The flaw in question is CVE-2023-46604, a critical severity (CVSS v3 score:
10.0) RCE that allows attackers to execute arbitrary shell commands by
exploiting class types in the OpenWire protocol.

According to Apache's disclosure on October 27, 2023, this vulnerability
affects the following Apache ActiveMQ and Legacy OpenWire Module versions:

  * Versions before 5.18.3 in the 5.18.x series
  * Versions before 5.17.6 in the 5.17.x series
  * Versions before 5.16.7 in the 5.16.x series
  * All versions before 5.15.16

To address this issue, fixes have been released in versions 5.15.16, 5.16.7,
5.17.6, and 5.18.3. It's recommended to upgrade to one of these versions to
enhance your IT security.

Tags: [#CyberSecurity](https://infosec.exchange/tags/CyberSecurity)
[#RCE](https://infosec.exchange/tags/RCE)
[#ApacheActiveMQ](https://infosec.exchange/tags/ApacheActiveMQ)

[BleepingComputer](https://www.bleepingcomputer.com/news/security/3-000-apache-
activemq-servers-vulnerable-to-rce-attacks-exposed-online/)

posts.content:
"⚠️ Critical RCE Alert: 3,000 Apache ActiveMQ Servers at Risk! ⚠️"

Over 3,000 Apache ActiveMQ servers are exposed online, vulnerable to a
critical RCE flaw (CVE-2023-46604, CVSS v3: 10.0). Immediate patching is urged
to prevent potential data theft and network compromise. Stay vigilant! 🛡️💻

Apache ActiveMQ is an open-source message broker for secure communication
between clients and servers, supporting Java and various cross-language
clients and protocols like AMQP, MQTT, OpenWire, and STOMP.

The flaw in question is CVE-2023-46604, a critical severity (CVSS v3 score:
10.0) RCE that allows attackers to execute arbitrary shell commands by
exploiting class types in the OpenWire protocol.

According to Apache's disclosure on October 27, 2023, this vulnerability
affects the following Apache ActiveMQ and Legacy OpenWire Module versions:

  * Versions before 5.18.3 in the 5.18.x series
  * Versions before 5.17.6 in the 5.17.x series
  * Versions before 5.16.7 in the 5.16.x series
  * All versions before 5.15.16

To address this issue, fixes have been released in versions 5.15.16, 5.16.7,
5.17.6, and 5.18.3. It's recommended to upgrade to one of these versions to
enhance your IT security.

Tags: [#CyberSecurity](https://infosec.exchange/tags/CyberSecurity)

posts.content:
[@BleepingComputer](https://infosec.exchange/@BleepingComputer) CVE-2023-46604
(CVSS: 10.0 critical severity, disclosed 26 October 2023 by Apache)  
Apache ActiveMQ is vulnerable to Remote Code Execution.The vulnerability may
allow a remote attacker with network access to a broker to run arbitrary shell
commands by manipulating serialized class types in the OpenWire protocol to
cause the broker to instantiate any class on the classpath. Users are
recommended to upgrade to version 5.15.16, 5.16.7, 5.17.6, or 5.18.3, which
fixes this issue.

The Netherlands' National Cyber Security Centrum (NCSC) states that Proof of
Concept has been published publicly, and that they received a report from a
trusted partner that the vulnerability has been actively and specifically
exploited.
[https://advisories.ncsc.nl/advisory?id=NCSC-2023-0561](https://advisories.ncsc.nl/advisory?id=NCSC-2023-0561)

posts.content:
The Apache Foundation has an update on the ActiveMQ vulnerability
CVE-2023-46604 (10/10 CVSS RCE).

Says both "Classic" and "Artemis" versions of its software are vulnerable and
recommends patching:
[https://activemq.apache.org/news/cve-2023-46604](https://activemq.apache.org/news/cve-2023-46604)

In the meantime, Huntress and ArcticWolf say this bug has been exploited as
far back as Oct 10, meaning it was a zero-day before the patch came out:
[https://www.huntress.com/blog/critical-vulnerability-exploitation-of-apache-
activemq-cve-2023-46604](https://www.huntress.com/blog/critical-vulnerability-
exploitation-of-apache-activemq-cve-2023-46604)

posts.content:
In our classic sensor network (we're still wiring up our 10x improved sensors
to the data machine) we've caught one IP attempting to find and pwn Apache
ActiveMQ (CVE-2023-46604) kit.

Message queues should never be wired up to the big scary internet. Use
WireGuard/Tailscale if you have to do remote queue ops.

attempt?days=30](https://viz.greynoise.io/tag/apache-activemq-rce-

posts.content:
New exploit out in the wild, this time it affects ActiveMQ:

Apache ActiveMQ is vulnerable to Remote Code Execution.The vulnerability may
allow a remote attacker with network access to a broker to run arbitrary shell
commands by manipulating serialized class types in the OpenWire protocol to
cause the broker to instantiate any class on the classpath.

It's recommended to upgrade to version 5.15.16, 5.16.7, 5.17.6, or 5.18.3, to
fix this issue.

[https://www.cve.org/CVERecord?id=CVE-2023-46604](https://www.cve.org/CVERecord?id=CVE-2023-46604)

[#activeMQ](https://area51.social/tags/activeMQ)
[#exploit](https://area51.social/tags/exploit)
[#cve](https://area51.social/tags/cve)

CVE-2023-46604.description:
The Java OpenWire protocol marshaller is vulnerable to Remote Code 
Execution. This vulnerability may allow a remote attacker with network 
access to either a Java-based OpenWire broker or client to run arbitrary
 shell commands by manipulating serialized class types in the OpenWire 
protocol to cause either the client or the broker (respectively) to 
instantiate any class on the classpath.

Users are recommended to upgrade
 both brokers and clients to version 5.15.16, 5.16.7, 5.17.6, or 5.18.3 
which fixes this issue.

posts.content:
To help mitigate the [#atlassian](https://infosec.exchange/tags/atlassian)
[#confluence](https://infosec.exchange/tags/confluence)
[#ransomware](https://infosec.exchange/tags/ransomware) as a result of
[#cve202322518](https://infosec.exchange/tags/cve202322518)

1\. Dont run Jira or Confluence as root on the linux box. (Good advice for any
web app).

2\. Install the database on a different machine from the web server. Even if
your web server gets compromised and encrypted the data in Jira will remain
safe and recoverable.

3\. Encrypt the database tables for added protection against data theft.

4\. Keep multiple daily server backups / snapshots so you can recover from a
clean backup.

5\. Monitor outbound traffic for spikes realted to data exfiltration.

6\. Monitor CPU for spikes that might represent encryption activity.

MOST IMPORTANT - DONT RUN Atlassian products on the open Internet!

[#incidentresponse](https://infosec.exchange/tags/incidentresponse)

posts.content:
Atlassian has raised the severity of CVE-2023-22518 from CVSS 9.1 to 🔟, the
highest critical rating, due to a change in the attack's scope. This critical
security advisory concerns CVE-2023-22518, which highlights an improper
authorization vulnerability in Confluence Data Center and Server. The
vulnerability, now rated at a CVSS score of 🔟, the highest critical rating,
enables an unauthenticated attacker to reset Confluence and create an
administrator account, potentially leading to a complete data compromise.
Atlassian has detected active exploitation and strongly recommends immediate
application of the provided fixes. If immediate patching is not possible,
temporary mitigations such as network restrictions and specific configuration
changes can be implemented. It is imperative for customers to thoroughly
review their threat detection systems for any signs of compromise and follow
their security incident response plan if any evidence of a breach is
discovered. 🛡️

Source: [https://confluence.atlassian.com/security/cve-2023-22518-improper-
authorization-vulnerability-in-confluence-data-center-and-
server-1311473907.html](https://confluence.atlassian.com/security/cve-2023-22518-improper-
authorization-vulnerability-in-confluence-data-center-and-
server-1311473907.html)

posts.content:
To help mitigate the [#atlassian](https://infosec.exchange/tags/atlassian)
[#confluence](https://infosec.exchange/tags/confluence)
[#ransomware](https://infosec.exchange/tags/ransomware) as a result of
[#cve202322518](https://infosec.exchange/tags/cve202322518)

1\. Dont run Jira or Confluence as root on the linux box. (Good advice for any
web app).

2\. Install the database on a different machine from the web server. Even if
your web server gets compromised and encrypted the data in Jira will remain
safe and recoverable.

3\. Encrypt the database tables for added protection against data theft.

4\. Keep multiple daily server backups / snapshots so you can recover from a
clean backup.

5\. Monitor outbound traffic for spikes realted to data exfiltration.

6\. Monitor CPU for spikes that might represent encryption activity.

MOST IMPORTANT - DONT RUN Atlassian products on the open Internet!

posts.content:
Atlassian has raised the severity of CVE-2023-22518 from CVSS 9.1 to 🔟, the
highest critical rating, due to a change in the attack's scope. This critical
security advisory concerns CVE-2023-22518, which highlights an improper
authorization vulnerability in Confluence Data Center and Server. The
vulnerability, now rated at a CVSS score of 🔟, the highest critical rating,
enables an unauthenticated attacker to reset Confluence and create an
administrator account, potentially leading to a complete data compromise.
Atlassian has detected active exploitation and strongly recommends immediate
application of the provided fixes. If immediate patching is not possible,
temporary mitigations such as network restrictions and specific configuration
changes can be implemented. It is imperative for customers to thoroughly
review their threat detection systems for any signs of compromise and follow
their security incident response plan if any evidence of a breach is
discovered. 🛡️

Source: [https://confluence.atlassian.com/security/cve-2023-22518-improper-
authorization-vulnerability-in-confluence-data-center-and-
server-1311473907.html](https://confluence.atlassian.com/security/cve-2023-22518-improper-
authorization-vulnerability-in-confluence-data-center-and-
server-1311473907.html)

[#improperauthorization](https://infosec.exchange/tags/improperauthorization)

CVE-2023-22518.description:
All versions of Confluence Data Center and Server are affected by this unexploited vulnerability. This Improper Authorization vulnerability allows an unauthenticated attacker to reset Confluence and create a Confluence instance administrator account. Using this account, an attacker can then perform all administrative actions that are available to Confluence instance administrator leading to - but not limited to - full loss of confidentiality, integrity and availability. 

Atlassian Cloud sites are not affected by this vulnerability. If your Confluence site is accessed via an atlassian.net domain, it is hosted by Atlassian and is not vulnerable to this issue.

posts.content:
**Aqua** reports that Kinsing threat actors are exploiting CVE-2023-4911 (7.8
high severity, disclosed 03 October 2023 by Qualsys) dubbed "Looney Tunables"
to breach cloud environments. CVE-2017-9841 (9.8 critical, PHPUnit RCE
vulnerability disclosed 19 November 2017) is first leveraged for initial
access. The end goal of the attack appears to be to extract credentials
associated with the cloud service provider for follow-on attacks. Aqua states
that the threat actor has been actively involved in cryptojacking operations.
IOC provided.  
 **Link:** [https://blog.aquasec.com/loony-tunables-vulnerability-exploited-
by-kinsing](https://blog.aquasec.com/loony-tunables-vulnerability-exploited-

posts.content:
**Aqua** reports that Kinsing threat actors are exploiting CVE-2023-4911 (7.8
high severity, disclosed 03 October 2023 by Qualsys) dubbed "Looney Tunables"
to breach cloud environments. CVE-2017-9841 (9.8 critical, PHPUnit RCE
vulnerability disclosed 19 November 2017) is first leveraged for initial
access. The end goal of the attack appears to be to extract credentials
associated with the cloud service provider for follow-on attacks. Aqua states
that the threat actor has been actively involved in cryptojacking operations.
IOC provided.  
 **Link:** [https://blog.aquasec.com/loony-tunables-vulnerability-exploited-
by-kinsing](https://blog.aquasec.com/loony-tunables-vulnerability-exploited-
by-kinsing)

posts.content:
Hackers exploit Looney Tunables Linux bug, steal cloud creds

The operators of the Kinsing malware are targeting cloud environments with
systems vulnerable to "Looney Tunables," a Linux security issue identified as
CVE-2023-4911 that allows a local attacker to gain root privileges on the
system.

🔗️ [Bleepingcomputer] [https://link.is.it/usa73c](https://link.is.it/usa73c)

posts.content:
Aqua Nautilus meldet ersten erfolgreichen Exploit der Linux-Sicherheitslücke
„Looney Tunables“ (CVE-2023-4911), vermutet Kinsing dahinter.

[https://www.scmagazine.com/news/exploited-looney-tunables-linux-privileged-
escalation-bug-linked-to-kinsing-threat-
actor](https://www.scmagazine.com/news/exploited-looney-tunables-linux-
privileged-escalation-bug-linked-to-kinsing-threat-actor)

CVE-2023-4911.description: A buffer overflow was discovered in the GNU C Library's dynamic loader ld.so while processing the GLIBC_TUNABLES environment variable. This issue could allow a local attacker to use maliciously crafted GLIBC_TUNABLES environment variables when launching binaries with SUID permission to execute code with elevated privileges.

posts.content:
Unit 42 published a threat brief on "Citrix Bleed," after their Incident
Response and Managed Threat Hunting teams have observed ransomware groups
exploiting CVE-2023-4966 (NVD 7.5 high/vendor 9.4 critical, disclosed 10
October 2023 by Citrix, reported exploited in the wild as a zero day by
Mandiant on 17 October, added to CISA Known Exploited Vulnerabilities Catalog
on 18 October, proof of concept by AssetNote on 24 October). IOC provided.  
 **Link:** [https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/threat-brief-
cve-2023-4966-netscaler-citrix-
bleed/](https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/threat-brief-
cve-2023-4966-netscaler-citrix-bleed/)

posts.content:
**Mandiant** provided an updated blog regarding Citrix Netscaler ADC and
Gateway CVE-2023-4966 (9.4 high severity, disclosed 10 October 2023 by Citrix)
exploitation. Mandiant then found evidence of zero-day exploitation in the
wild beginning in late August 2023. Mandiant discusses artifacts that can be
used to identify exploitation activity and highlights some of the post
exploitation techniques observed during the incident response investigations.  
 **Link:** [https://www.mandiant.com/resources/blog/session-hijacking-citrix-
cve-2023-4966](https://www.mandiant.com/resources/blog/session-hijacking-
citrix-cve-2023-4966)

posts.content:
Im Kontext der aktuellen Citrix Schwachstelle
([https://cert.at/de/aktuelles/2023/10/cve-2023-4966-0day](https://cert.at/de/aktuelles/2023/10/cve-2023-4966-0day))
hab ich einen spannenden Effekt wieder mal beobachtet:

Die Frage vom Management "Sind wir betroffen?" ist nicht immer einfach zu
beantworten. Man müsste Logs durchgraben und eventuell auch noch Forensik
machen, um sicherzustellen, dass es entweder keinen Session-Reconnects durch
Tätergruppen gab und falls doch, es dann keine relevante Aktivität in diesen
Session gab. Schwierig und aufwändig.

Daher wird manchmal unbewusst eine andere Frage beantwortet, nämlich "Haben
wir wir uns an unsere Patch-Policy gehalten?", oder noch einfacher: "Haben wir
was falsch gemacht?". Das ist einfach zu beantworten: "Patch kam am 10. raus,
wir haben den am nächsten Tag eingespielt. Alles gut, man kann uns nichts
vorwerfen."

Es ist aber die Natur von 0-day Schwachstellen, dass es auch diejenigen
treffen kann, die nichts falsch gemacht haben. Ja, das ist unangenehm. Für den
Techniker. Für den CISO. Und im Fall der aktuellen Citrix-Schwachstelle kann
man sich auch kaum vorwerfen lassen, dass das Teil aus dem Internet erreichbar
war.

Daher: bitte macht keine Abkürzungen. Schaut auf eure Logs. Von Mandiant gibt
es Tipps dazu, und von uns ein Script. Siehe
[https://cert.at/de/aktuelles/2023/10/cve-2023-4966-0day](https://cert.at/de/aktuelles/2023/10/cve-2023-4966-0day)

posts.content:
Mandiant has a new blog out on
[#CitrixBleed](https://cyberplace.social/tags/CitrixBleed) which backs up a
key point from my blog [https://www.mandiant.com/resources/blog/session-
hijacking-citrix-
cve-2023-4966](https://www.mandiant.com/resources/blog/session-hijacking-
citrix-cve-2023-4966)

The initial exploit string isn’t logged.. at all.

There’s some good hunting stuff in the blog (ICA sessions) - I’d say combine
it with the GetUserName thing in my blog for assurance.

The other big take away is a ton of orgs have been compromised and don’t know
yet. [#threatintel](https://cyberplace.social/tags/threatintel)

posts.content:
Ransomware groups are among the attackers targeting NetScaler ADC and Gateway
Devices to exploit CVE-2023-4966 and bypass multifactor authentication.
NetScaler urges users to "immediately" update their software as well as kill
"all active and persistent sessions," since attackers can grab them from
memory to defeat access controls.  
[https://www.databreachtoday.com/ransomware-groups-exploiting-unpatched-
netscaler-devices-a-23431](https://www.databreachtoday.com/ransomware-groups-
exploiting-unpatched-netscaler-devices-a-23431)  
h/t [@GossiTheDog](https://cyberplace.social/@GossiTheDog)

CVE-2023-4966.description: Sensitive information disclosure in NetScaler ADC and NetScaler Gateway when configured as a Gateway (VPN virtual server, ICA Proxy, CVPN, RDP Proxy) or AAA ?virtual?server.

posts.content:
Well, that didn't take long.
[#cve202346747](https://infosec.exchange/tags/cve202346747) has now been
reported by F5 as being exploited in the wild. This can be found in an updated
section of the advisory towards the bottom at
[https://my.f5.com/manage/s/article/K000137353](https://my.f5.com/manage/s/article/K000137353).

Interestingly enough, the in-the-wild exploitation is using the SQL injection
vulnerability (CVE-2023-46748) in conjunction with the AJP request smuggling
attack to achieve access. This vulnerability was also included in the same KB
advisory as the AJP request smuggling attack.

Originally I wasn't sure if the SQL injection vuln report was the other
security researcher(s) who had also reported the AJP Request Smuggling content
to F5, but given the way this is being exploited in the wild it sure looks
like this is the case.

account.note: Security Consultant. Not affiliated with Red Hat. I just like the hat.

posts.content:
Since [@pdnuclei](https://bird.makeup/users/pdnuclei) has posted a full PoC
for [#cve202346747](https://infosec.exchange/tags/cve202346747) already, we've
updated our blog post at [https://www.praetorian.com/blog/refresh-
compromising-f5-big-ip-with-request-smuggling-
cve-2023-46747/](https://www.praetorian.com/blog/refresh-compromising-f5-big-
ip-with-request-smuggling-cve-2023-46747/) with all the technical details.

Kudos to [@rootxharsh](https://bird.makeup/users/rootxharsh) and
[@iamnoooob](https://bird.makeup/users/iamnoooob) for SUCH a quick
reproduction of the bug as well!

A warning for folks who are going to start spraying this around though:

The process of abusing AJP request smuggling causes Tomcat and Apache to get
out of sync. So as you send more of these requests, the de-sync gets worse.
Eventually the server gets so out of sync that it becomes incapable of
actually serving the correct site once you ask for it.

During testing we regularly would get our F5-BIGIP so jammed up that it was
just faster to do a full server reboot than it was to wait for things to clear
out normally. There's a secondary bug here in that if you do this enough,
you'll eventually catch the login session of someone else trying to hit the
server, but given the fact that you can get RCE through this as well, it seems
not to be as huge of a deal.

I do hope folks patched though - if you weren't paying attention on
Thursday/Friday you're gonna get snuck by this one pretty badly. A 72 hour
window isn't a massive amount of time unfortunately.

For what it's worth, at a glance there wasn't anything SUPER insane exposed on
the internet when we did a check. We did find one cisa.gov server, which we
notified them about and it was taken down before the ball started rolling on
this stuff. Lots and lots of telecoms though.

account.note: Security Consultant. Not affiliated with Red Hat. I just like the hat.

posts.content:
Well, that didn't take long.
[#cve202346747](https://infosec.exchange/tags/cve202346747) has now been
reported by F5 as being exploited in the wild. This can be found in an updated
section of the advisory towards the bottom at
[https://my.f5.com/manage/s/article/K000137353](https://my.f5.com/manage/s/article/K000137353).

Interestingly enough, the in-the-wild exploitation is using the SQL injection
vulnerability (CVE-2023-46748) in conjunction with the AJP request smuggling
attack to achieve access. This vulnerability was also included in the same KB
advisory as the AJP request smuggling attack.

Originally I wasn't sure if the SQL injection vuln report was the other
security researcher(s) who had also reported the AJP Request Smuggling content
to F5, but given the way this is being exploited in the wild it sure looks
like this is the case.

account.note: Security Consultant. Not affiliated with Red Hat. I just like the hat.

posts.content:
Since [@pdnuclei](https://bird.makeup/users/pdnuclei) has posted a full PoC
for [#cve202346747](https://infosec.exchange/tags/cve202346747) already, we've
updated our blog post at [https://www.praetorian.com/blog/refresh-
compromising-f5-big-ip-with-request-smuggling-
cve-2023-46747/](https://www.praetorian.com/blog/refresh-compromising-f5-big-
ip-with-request-smuggling-cve-2023-46747/) with all the technical details.

Kudos to [@rootxharsh](https://bird.makeup/users/rootxharsh) and
[@iamnoooob](https://bird.makeup/users/iamnoooob) for SUCH a quick
reproduction of the bug as well!

A warning for folks who are going to start spraying this around though:

The process of abusing AJP request smuggling causes Tomcat and Apache to get
out of sync. So as you send more of these requests, the de-sync gets worse.
Eventually the server gets so out of sync that it becomes incapable of
actually serving the correct site once you ask for it.

During testing we regularly would get our F5-BIGIP so jammed up that it was
just faster to do a full server reboot than it was to wait for things to clear
out normally. There's a secondary bug here in that if you do this enough,
you'll eventually catch the login session of someone else trying to hit the
server, but given the fact that you can get RCE through this as well, it seems
not to be as huge of a deal.

I do hope folks patched though - if you weren't paying attention on
Thursday/Friday you're gonna get snuck by this one pretty badly. A 72 hour
window isn't a massive amount of time unfortunately.

For what it's worth, at a glance there wasn't anything SUPER insane exposed on
the internet when we did a check. We did find one cisa.gov server, which we
notified them about and it was taken down before the ball started rolling on
this stuff. Lots and lots of telecoms though.

account.note: Security Consultant. Not affiliated with Red Hat. I just like the hat.

CVE-2023-46747.description: Undisclosed requests may bypass configuration utility authentication, allowing an attacker with network access to the BIG-IP system through the management port and/or self IP addresses to execute arbitrary system commands.  Note: Software versions which have reached End of Technical Support (EoTS) are not evaluated

posts.content:
Well, that didn't take long.
[#cve202346747](https://infosec.exchange/tags/cve202346747) has now been
reported by F5 as being exploited in the wild. This can be found in an updated
section of the advisory towards the bottom at
[https://my.f5.com/manage/s/article/K000137353](https://my.f5.com/manage/s/article/K000137353).

Interestingly enough, the in-the-wild exploitation is using the SQL injection
vulnerability (CVE-2023-46748) in conjunction with the AJP request smuggling
attack to achieve access. This vulnerability was also included in the same KB
advisory as the AJP request smuggling attack.

Originally I wasn't sure if the SQL injection vuln report was the other
security researcher(s) who had also reported the AJP Request Smuggling content
to F5, but given the way this is being exploited in the wild it sure looks
like this is the case.

CVE-2023-46748.description:
An authenticated SQL injection vulnerability exists in the BIG-IP Configuration utility which 

may allow an authenticated attacker with network access to the Configuration utility through the BIG-IP management port and/or self IP addresses to execute arbitrary system commands.

 Note: Software versions which have reached End of Technical Support (EoTS) are not evaluated

posts.content:
🚪 Alert: 'Effluence' Backdoor Persists Despite Patching Atlassian Confluence
Servers  
➥ [@thehackernews](https://infosec.exchange/@thehackernews)

The web shell, made up of a loader and payload, is passive, allowing requests
to pass through it unnoticed until a request matching a specific parameter is
provided, at which point it triggers its malicious behavior by executing a
series of actions.

[http://thehackernews.com/2023/11/alert-effluence-backdoor-
persists.html](http://thehackernews.com/2023/11/alert-effluence-backdoor-

posts.content:
**Aon** identified a unique Atlassian Confluence backdoor that persists even
after patching CVE-2023-22515. It grants persistent remote access to every web
page on the server, including the unauthenticated login page, without the need
for a valid user account. The web shell (dubbed "Effluence") is passive,
allowing requests to pass through it unnoticed until a request matching a
specific parameter is provided, at which point it triggers its malicious
behavior by executing a series of actions. No IOC, but detection methods and
YARA Rule provided.  
 **Links:** [https://www.aon.com/cyber-solutions/aon_cyber_labs/detecting-
effluence-an-unauthenticated-confluence-web-shell/](https://www.aon.com/cyber-
solutions/aon_cyber_labs/detecting-effluence-an-unauthenticated-confluence-
web-shell/) and [https://thehackernews.com/2023/11/alert-effluence-backdoor-
persists.html](https://thehackernews.com/2023/11/alert-effluence-backdoor-
persists.html)

[#AtlassianConfluence](https://infosec.exchange/tags/AtlassianConfluence)

posts.content:
A heavy Confluence news day: **Huntress** can also confirm active exploitation
of Atlassian Confluence Data Center and Confluence Server (CVE-2023-22518)
starting on November 3. Huntress was able to identify exploitation shortly
after patch release due to adversary reliance on common post-exploitation
behaviors. IOC and PowerShell commands.  
 **Link:** [https://www.huntress.com/blog/confluence-to-cerber-exploitation-
of-cve-2023-22518-for-ransomware-
deployment](https://www.huntress.com/blog/confluence-to-cerber-exploitation-
of-cve-2023-22518-for-ransomware-deployment)

posts.content:
**CISA** adds CVE-2023-22518 to its Known Exploited Vulnerabilities (KEV)
Catalog. First disclosed 30 October 2023 by Atlassian, its CVSS score changed
from 9.1 critical severity to 10.0 due to changed scope. Proof of Concept and
technical details are available, and it's been observed exploited in
ransomware attacks by Rapid7.  
 **Link:** [https://www.cisa.gov/news-events/alerts/2023/11/07/cisa-adds-one-
known-exploited-vulnerability-catalog](https://www.cisa.gov/news-
events/alerts/2023/11/07/cisa-adds-one-known-exploited-vulnerability-catalog)

In case you missed it (because I had), **Atlassian** updated their security
advisory on CVE-2023-22518: _" we observed several active exploits and reports
of threat actors using ransomware. We have escalated CVE-2023-22518 from CVSS
9.1 to 10, the highest critical rating, due to the change in the scope of the
attack."_ CVSS:3.0/AV:N/AC:L/PR:N/UI:N/S:C/C:H/I:H/A:H  
 **Link:** [https://confluence.atlassian.com/security/cve-2023-22518-improper-

posts.content:
**Rapid7** is observing exploitation of Atlassian Confluence in multiple
customer environments, with some of the exploits targeting CVE-2023-22518 and
even CVE-2023-22515, potentially leading to ransomware deployment. Edit: Post-
exploitation behavior and IOC included.

CVE-2023-22515 is an actively exploited broken access control zero-day
vulnerability that was disclosed on 04 October 2023 with a CVSS score of
**10.0 critical** , that Microsoft observed being exploited by Chinese state
hackers.  
**Link:** [https://www.rapid7.com/blog/post/2023/11/06/etr-rapid7-observed-
exploitation-of-atlassian-confluence-
cve-2023-22518/](https://www.rapid7.com/blog/post/2023/11/06/etr-
rapid7-observed-exploitation-of-atlassian-confluence-cve-2023-22518/)

posts.content:
The security team at consulting firm AON has published an analysis of
Effluence, a backdoor planted on Atlassian Confluence servers that have been
exploited using the CVE-2023-22515 vulnerability.

The zero-day was used by a suspected Chinese APT (Storm-0062) in limited
attacks since mid-September. AON did not attribute the backdoor to any threat
actor yet.

[https://www.aon.com/cyber-solutions/aon_cyber_labs/detecting-effluence-an-
unauthenticated-confluence-web-shell/](https://www.aon.com/cyber-
solutions/aon_cyber_labs/detecting-effluence-an-unauthenticated-confluence-
web-shell/)

posts.content:
Cybersecurity firm Rapid7 said it observed the exploitation of CVE-2023-22518
and CVE-2023-22515 in multiple customer environments, some of which have been
leveraged for the deployment of Cerber (aka C3RB3R) ransomware.
[https://thehackernews.com/2023/11/experts-warn-of-ransomware-
hackers.html](https://thehackernews.com/2023/11/experts-warn-of-ransomware-
hackers.html)

CVE-2023-22515.description:
Atlassian has been made aware of an issue reported by a handful of customers where external attackers may have exploited a previously unknown vulnerability in publicly accessible Confluence Data Center and Server instances to create unauthorized Confluence administrator accounts and access Confluence instances. 

Atlassian Cloud sites are not affected by this vulnerability. If your Confluence site is accessed via an atlassian.net domain, it is hosted by Atlassian and is not vulnerable to this issue.

posts.content:
🧰 Microsoft spotted the exploitation of a SysAid zero-day vulnerability in
limited attacks carried out by the Lace Tempest group  
➥ [@securityaffairs](https://infosec.exchange/@securityaffairs)

「 The Lace Tempest operators exploited the vulnerability to issue commands via
the SysAid software to deliver a loader for the Gracewire malware (aka
FlawedGrace). The malware enabled human-operated activity, including lateral
movement, data theft, and ransomware deployment 」

[#SysAid](https://mastodon.social/tags/SysAid)

posts.content:
[@avoidthehack](https://infosec.exchange/@avoidthehack)
[@AAKL](https://noc.social/@AAKL) Yep, I tooted about it yesterday morning
while the news was fresh. There's a Microsoft Threat Intelligence
[tweet](https://twitter.com/msftsecintel/status/1722444141081076219). The
official SysAid [security advisory](https://www.sysaid.com/blog/service-
desk/on-premise-software-security-vulnerability-notification) describes post-
compromise activity and includes PowerShell commands and Indicators of
Compromise. The Huntress [article](https://www.huntress.com/blog/critical-
vulnerability-sysaid-cve-2023-47246) contains technical analysis and
additional IOC.

CISA and federal agencies are aware of the exploited Zero-Day, and are likely
to add at least 2-3 to the Known Exploited Vulnerabilities Catalog soon.

SysAid IT support software in limited attacks by Lace Tempest, a threat actor
that distributes Clop ransomware. Microsoft notified SysAid about the issue
(CVE-2023-47246), which they immediately patched.

account.note: A task force comprised of our SophosLabs, SecOps, and SophosAI teams working together towards one goal: protecting our customers.

posts.content:
From SysAid’s write up about active attacks attributed to Cl0p.

"\- Checks all running processes for any process beginning with the name
“Sophos” [and only Sophos] and if found, exits.  
\- If no matching processes are found, starts the user.exe malware."

SysAid On-Prem Software customers should read and apply the update discussed
to address CVE-2023-47246 Vulnerability.

[https://www.sysaid.com/blog/service-desk/on-premise-software-security-
vulnerability-notification](https://www.sysaid.com/blog/service-desk/on-
premise-software-security-vulnerability-notification)

posts.content:
Semi-occasional mention of a decade-old and long-unresolved HP and HPE iLO
vulnerability to brute-forcing of a network-accessible management processor
password:

CVE-2013-4786

[https://support.hpe.com/hpesc/public/docDisplay?docId=emr_na-c04197764](https://support.hpe.com/hpesc/public/docDisplay?docId=emr_na-c04197764)

This IPMI vulnerability effects most HP and HPE Integrity Itanium servers
running OpenVMS, or whatever other operating system happens to be running
“upstairs” from the iLO, so long as IPMI is enabled and accessible.

Yes, various of these servers are still in use.

To disable IPMI on most iLO management processors:

MP:CM> sa -lanipmi d

CVE-2013-4786.description: The IPMI 2.0 specification supports RMCP+ Authenticated Key-Exchange Protocol (RAKP) authentication, which allows remote attackers to obtain password hashes and conduct offline password guessing attacks by obtaining the HMAC from a RAKP message 2 response from a BMC.

posts.content:
**Microsoft** Security Response Center (MSRC) published 3 security advisories
tonight:

  * [CVE-2023-36014](https://msrc.microsoft.com/update-guide/en-US/advisory/CVE-2023-36014) (CVSS: 7.3 high severity) Microsoft Edge (Chromium-based) Remote Code Execution Vulnerability. Check out the FAQ for some interesting tidbits.
  * [CVE-2023-5996](https://msrc.microsoft.com/update-guide/en-US/advisory/CVE-2023-5996) (CVSS: unknown) Use after free in WebAudio. First disclosed by [Google](https://chromereleases.googleblog.com/2023/11/stable-channel-update-for-desktop.html) on 07 November 2023
  * [CVE-2023-36024](https://msrc.microsoft.com/update-guide/en-US/advisory/CVE-2023-36024) (7.1 high) Microsoft Edge (Chromium-based) Elevation of Privilege Vulnerability. It has an interesting FAQ too.

2 of 3 are marked not publicly disclosed, not exploited, and exploitation less
likely. CVE-2023-5996 doesn't include any addtl information.

posts.content:
**Rapid7** Velociraptor security advisory: CVE-2023-5950 (CVSSv3: 8.6 high
severity) Rapid7 Velociraptor versions prior to 0.7.0-4 suffer from a
reflected cross site scripting (XSS) vulnerability. This vulnerability allows
attackers to inject JS into the error path, potentially leading to
unauthorized execution of scripts within a user's web browser. This
vulnerability is fixed in version 0.7.0-4 and a patch is available to
download. Patches are also available for version 0.6.9 (0.6.9-1). This issue
affects the server only. No mention of exploitation.  
 **Link:**
[https://www.rapid7.com/blog/post/2023/11/10/cve-2023-5950-rapid7-velociraptor-
reflected-
xss/](https://www.rapid7.com/blog/post/2023/11/10/cve-2023-5950-rapid7-velociraptor-
reflected-xss/)

Patches are also available for version 0.6.9 (0.6.9-1).

CVE-2023-38547 (9.9 critical, allows for RCE) and CVE-2023-38548 (9.8
critical, acquire the NTLM hash). No mention of exploitation in the wild.  
 **Link:** [https://www.veeam.com/kb4508](https://www.veeam.com/kb4508)

posts.content:
Security researcher Gergely Kalman has published a technical write-up on
BatSignal (CVE-2022-26704), an unprivileged user to root elevation of
privilege vulnerability in macOS.

[https://gergelykalman.com/no-CVE-batsignal-a-macos-
lpe.html](https://gergelykalman.com/no-CVE-batsignal-a-macos-lpe.html)

CVE-2022-26704.description: A validation issue existed in the handling of symlinks and was addressed with improved validation of symlinks. This issue is fixed in macOS Monterey 12.4. An app may be able to gain elevated privileges.

posts.content:
[@avoidthehack](https://infosec.exchange/@avoidthehack) CISA just added
CVE-2023-29552 (CVSSv3: 7.5 high severity) Service Location Protocol (SLP)
Denial-of-Service Vulnerability to the KEV  
 **Link:** [https://www.cisa.gov/news-events/alerts/2023/11/08/cisa-adds-one-
known-exploited-vulnerability-catalog](https://www.cisa.gov/news-
events/alerts/2023/11/08/cisa-adds-one-known-exploited-vulnerability-catalog)

CVE-2023-29552.description: The Service Location Protocol (SLP, RFC 2608) allows an unauthenticated, remote attacker to register arbitrary services. This could allow the attacker to use spoofed UDP traffic to conduct a denial-of-service attack with a significant amplification factor.

posts.content:
**Microsoft** Security Response Center (MSRC) published 3 security advisories
tonight:

  * [CVE-2023-36014](https://msrc.microsoft.com/update-guide/en-US/advisory/CVE-2023-36014) (CVSS: 7.3 high severity) Microsoft Edge (Chromium-based) Remote Code Execution Vulnerability. Check out the FAQ for some interesting tidbits.
  * [CVE-2023-5996](https://msrc.microsoft.com/update-guide/en-US/advisory/CVE-2023-5996) (CVSS: unknown) Use after free in WebAudio. First disclosed by [Google](https://chromereleases.googleblog.com/2023/11/stable-channel-update-for-desktop.html) on 07 November 2023
  * [CVE-2023-36024](https://msrc.microsoft.com/update-guide/en-US/advisory/CVE-2023-36024) (7.1 high) Microsoft Edge (Chromium-based) Elevation of Privilege Vulnerability. It has an interesting FAQ too.

2 of 3 are marked not publicly disclosed, not exploited, and exploitation less
likely. CVE-2023-5996 doesn't include any addtl information.

posts.content:
In case you missed it (because I did): On 02 November, **Cisco** updated their
blog post about the actively exploited zero-days CVE-2023-20198 and
CVE-2023-20273, stating that they identified a new version of the implant, now
called BadCandy, and added expected response from the new version of the
implant against one of the HTTP requests used to check for infected device.  
 **Link:** [https://blog.talosintelligence.com/active-exploitation-of-cisco-
ios-xe-software/](https://blog.talosintelligence.com/active-exploitation-of-
cisco-ios-xe-software/)

posts.content:
Cisco updated their security advisory on Cisco IOS XE zero-days CVE-2023-20198
and CVE-2023-20273: Posted 17.3.8a for Base Release 17.3.8 on 30 October 2023,
and 17.9.3a for IOS XE Software Maintenance Upgrade (SMU) on 01 November 2023.

Updated fixed release table:

posts.content:

blog post about the actively exploited zero-days CVE-2023-20198 and
CVE-2023-20273, stating that they identified a new version of the implant, now
called BadCandy, and added expected response from the new version of the
implant against one of the HTTP requests used to check for infected device.  
 **Link:** [https://blog.talosintelligence.com/active-exploitation-of-cisco-

posts.content:
Cisco Talos has published a technical analysis of BadCandy, the implant
deployed on Cisco IOS XE routers via the two recent zero-days CVE-2023-20198
and CVE-2023-20273: [https://blog.talosintelligence.com/active-exploitation-
of-cisco-ios-xe-software/](https://blog.talosintelligence.com/active-
exploitation-of-cisco-ios-xe-software/)

Talos says the malware is now at v3, showing that threat actors are still
actively modifying their attacks and malware to maintain access to the
compromised boxes. The latest v3 modifications appear to have worked, as
Shadowserver has stopped detecting infected systems:
[https://mastodon.social/@shadowserver@infosec.exchange/111354144609010594](https://mastodon.social/@shadowserver@infosec.exchange/111354144609010594)

posts.content:
🚨 [#Cisco](https://infosec.exchange/tags/Cisco)
[#IOSXE](https://infosec.exchange/tags/IOSXE)
[#CVE](https://infosec.exchange/tags/CVE)-2023-20198
[#CVE](https://infosec.exchange/tags/CVE)-2023-20273

We updated our [#IoC](https://infosec.exchange/tags/IoC) for exploit attempts
that hit our honeypot. You can find them on
[#GitHub](https://infosec.exchange/tags/GitHub):
[https://github.com/SIFalcon/research/blob/main/CVE-2023-20198/ioc.txt](https://github.com/SIFalcon/research/blob/main/CVE-2023-20198/ioc.txt)

Based on modus operandi and infrastructure we managed to cluster certain
attacking hosts togehter ⬇️

We also saw new traffic to the Implant, this time from 107.175.229[.]142,
again via the user "cisco_support". Executed recon commands include:

show ip interface brief  
show ip dns view  
show ip name-servers

posts.content:
Exploit released for critical Cisco IOS XE flaw, many hosts still hacked

Public exploit code is now available for the critical Cisco IOS XE
vulnerability tracked as CVE-2023-20198 that was leveraged as a zero-day to
hack tens of thousands of devices.

🔗️ [Bleepingcomputer] [https://link.is.it/2uywz4](https://link.is.it/2uywz4)

CVE-2023-20198.description: Cisco is providing an update for the ongoing investigation into observed exploitation of the web UI feature in Cisco IOS XE Software. We are updating the list of fixed releases and adding the Software Checker. Our investigation has determined that the actors exploited two previously unknown issues. The attacker first exploited CVE-2023-20198 to gain initial access and issued a privilege 15 command to create a local user and password combination. This allowed the user to log in with normal user access. The attacker then exploited another component of the web UI feature, leveraging the new local user to elevate privilege to root and write the implant to the file system. Cisco has assigned CVE-2023-20273 to this issue. CVE-2023-20198 has been assigned a CVSS Score of 10.0. CVE-2023-20273 has been assigned a CVSS Score of 7.2. Both of these CVEs are being tracked by CSCwh87343.

posts.content:
In case you missed it (because I did): On 02 November, **Cisco** updated their
blog post about the actively exploited zero-days CVE-2023-20198 and
CVE-2023-20273, stating that they identified a new version of the implant, now
called BadCandy, and added expected response from the new version of the
implant against one of the HTTP requests used to check for infected device.  
 **Link:** [https://blog.talosintelligence.com/active-exploitation-of-cisco-
ios-xe-software/](https://blog.talosintelligence.com/active-exploitation-of-
cisco-ios-xe-software/)

posts.content:
**ASEC** summarized 17 months of a Kimsuky operation dubbed _Operation Covert
Stalker_. Kimsuky is a nation-state APT attributed to North Korea and assessed
to be in the Reconnaissance General Burueau (RGB). In the report (Korean
language only) ASEC states that Kimsuky sends phishing emails to targets
involved in the field of North Korea, exploiting CVE-2019-0708 (9.8 critical
RDP vulnerability allowing for RCE, added to KEV Catalog 03 November 2021) and
other unidentified vulnerabilities, adding remote control programs e.g.
AnyDesk and Quasar RAT etc., and encrypting systems with BlackBit ransomware.  
 **Link:**
[https://asec.ahnlab.com/en/58654/](https://asec.ahnlab.com/en/58654/)

CVE-2023-45283.description: The filepath package does not recognize paths with a \??\ prefix as special. On Windows, a path beginning with \??\ is a Root Local Device path equivalent to a path beginning with \\?\. Paths with a \??\ prefix may be used to access arbitrary locations on the system. For example, the path \??\c:\x is equivalent to the more common path c:\x. Before fix, Clean could convert a rooted path such as \a\..\??\b into the root local device path \??\b. Clean will now convert this to .\??\b. Similarly, Join(\, ??, b) could convert a seemingly innocent sequence of path elements into the root local device path \??\b. Join will now convert this to \.\??\b. In addition, with fix, IsAbs now correctly reports paths beginning with \??\ as absolute, and VolumeName correctly reports the \??\ prefix as a volume name.

posts.content:
Welcome to my new followers. I have taken possession of your souls, for which
I am _eternally_ grateful.

By way of [#introduction](https://infosec.exchange/tags/introduction), here
are a few things that I am sometimes known for:

  * I wrote the book [API Security in Action](https://www.manning.com/books/api-security-in-action) published by Manning. It covers a lot about modern application security, JWTs, OAuth, Kubernetes, and is secretly a tutorial on cryptography in disguise.

  * I discovered the [“Psychic Signatures”](https://neilmadden.blog/2022/04/19/psychic-signatures-in-java/) critical vulnerability in Java’s implementation of ECDSA signature verification (CVE-2022-21449).

  * My [blog](https://neilmadden.blog) has made its way onto [Hacker News](https://news.ycombinator.com/from?site=neilmadden.blog) a few times.

  * I’m fairly active in the [#OAuth](https://infosec.exchange/tags/OAuth) working group at the IETF. I used to be the Security Architect for ForgeRock (now part of Ping Identity).

In my past I have mostly been a software engineer. I also have a PhD in
computer science, for what it’s worth, but only my bank calls me Dr and my
daughter thinks I’m lying about that.

These days I run a company, [Illuminated Security](https://illuminated-
security.com), that provides AppSec and Applied Cryptography consultancy,
review, bespoke development, and training. I’m always happy to answer emails
(eventually!) on most topics.

CVE-2022-21449.description: Vulnerability in the Oracle Java SE, Oracle GraalVM Enterprise Edition product of Oracle Java SE (component: Libraries). Supported versions that are affected are Oracle Java SE: 17.0.2 and 18; Oracle GraalVM Enterprise Edition: 21.3.1 and 22.0.0.2. Easily exploitable vulnerability allows unauthenticated attacker with network access via multiple protocols to compromise Oracle Java SE, Oracle GraalVM Enterprise Edition. Successful attacks of this vulnerability can result in unauthorized creation, deletion or modification access to critical data or all Oracle Java SE, Oracle GraalVM Enterprise Edition accessible data. Note: This vulnerability applies to Java deployments, typically in clients running sandboxed Java Web Start applications or sandboxed Java applets, that load and run untrusted code (e.g., code that comes from the internet) and rely on the Java sandbox for security. This vulnerability can also be exploited by using APIs in the specified Component, e.g., through a web service which supplies data to the APIs. CVSS 3.1 Base Score 7.5 (Integrity impacts). CVSS Vector: (CVSS:3.1/AV:N/AC:L/PR:N/UI:N/S:U/C:N/I:H/A:N).

details how HTTP signatures can be bypassed because of an innocuous bug, and
how it can lead to the spoofing of Mastodon instances depending on their

cve-2023-42451/](https://scumjr.github.io/2023/11/07/usurping-mastodon-

CVE-2023-42451.description: Mastodon is a free, open-source social network server based on ActivityPub. Prior to versions 3.5.14, 4.0.10, 4.1.8, and 4.2.0-rc2, under certain circumstances, attackers can exploit a flaw in domain name normalization to spoof domains they do not own. Versions 3.5.14, 4.0.10, 4.1.8, and 4.2.0-rc2 contain a patch for this issue.

posts.content:
**Aqua** reports that Kinsing threat actors are exploiting CVE-2023-4911 (7.8
high severity, disclosed 03 October 2023 by Qualsys) dubbed "Looney Tunables"
to breach cloud environments. CVE-2017-9841 (9.8 critical, PHPUnit RCE
vulnerability disclosed 19 November 2017) is first leveraged for initial
access. The end goal of the attack appears to be to extract credentials
associated with the cloud service provider for follow-on attacks. Aqua states
that the threat actor has been actively involved in cryptojacking operations.
IOC provided.  
 **Link:** [https://blog.aquasec.com/loony-tunables-vulnerability-exploited-
by-kinsing](https://blog.aquasec.com/loony-tunables-vulnerability-exploited-

CVE-2023-20048.description: A vulnerability in the web services interface of Cisco Firepower Management Center (FMC) Software could allow an authenticated, remote attacker to execute certain unauthorized configuration commands on a Firepower Threat Defense (FTD) device that is managed by the FMC Software. This vulnerability is due to insufficient authorization of configuration commands that are sent through the web service interface. An attacker could exploit this vulnerability by authenticating to the FMC web services interface and sending a crafted HTTP request to an affected device. A successful exploit could allow the attacker to execute certain configuration commands on the targeted FTD device. To successfully exploit this vulnerability, an attacker would need valid credentials on the FMC Software.

posts.content:
Looking for some community input on this one, because I am a bit confused.
Could someone explain CVE-2022-23166 to me? I'm not looking to figure out how
to exploit it, but I am trying to get a better idea on what could happen. If
an endpoint has the Sysaid agent installed, does that mean there is a URL tied
that asset? Is that what this CVE is referring to? Any insight would be very
helpful because I want to protect against this, but I need to be able to
explain this to the team a little better.

[#security](https://infosec.exchange/tags/security)
[#CVE202223166](https://infosec.exchange/tags/CVE202223166)
[#Sysaid](https://infosec.exchange/tags/Sysaid)
[#confused](https://infosec.exchange/tags/confused)

CVE-2022-23166.description: Sysaid – Sysaid Local File Inclusion (LFI) – An unauthenticated attacker can access to the system by accessing to "/lib/tinymce/examples/index.html" path. in the "Insert/Edit Embedded Media" window Choose Type : iFrame and File/URL : [here is the LFI] Solution: Update to 22.2.20 cloud version, or to 22.1.64 on premise version.

posts.content:
In Feb of 2023 this year the Edge team replaced pdfium with a PDF reader from
Adobe. The project was a joint collaboration with Adobe focused quite a bit on
security and took us over a year to get it ready for release.

I was really worried we would get crushed with bugs. Adobe's original PDF
renderer was an old target of mine. It seems however the work we did paid off.
It took 8 months before Edge got their first external report in the PDF
renderer. [https://msrc.microsoft.com/update-
guide/vulnerability/CVE-2023-44323](https://msrc.microsoft.com/update-
guide/vulnerability/CVE-2023-44323)

CVE-2023-44323.description: Adobe Acrobat for Edge version 118.0.2088.46 (and earlier) is affected by a Use After Free vulnerability. An unauthenticated attacker could leverage this vulnerability to achieve an application denial-of-service in the context of the current user. Exploitation of this issue requires user interaction in that a victim must open a malicious file.

posts.content:
**The Hacker News:** Three unpatched high-severity security flaws have been
disclosed in the NGINX Ingress controller for Kubernetes that could be
weaponized by a threat actor to steal secret credentials from the cluster.

  * CVE-2022-4886 (CVSS score: 8.8) - Ingress-nginx path sanitization can be bypassed to obtain the credentials of the ingress-nginx controller
  * CVE-2023-5043 (CVSS score: 7.6) - Ingress-nginx annotation injection causes arbitrary command execution
  * CVE-2023-5044 (CVSS score: 7.6) - Code injection via nginx.ingress.kubernetes.io/permanent-redirect annotation

 **Link:** [https://thehackernews.com/2023/10/urgent-new-security-flaws-
discovered-in.html](https://thehackernews.com/2023/10/urgent-new-security-
flaws-discovered-in.html)

[#Kubernetes](https://infosec.exchange/tags/Kubernetes)

posts.content:
"[#IBMi](https://infosec.exchange/tags/IBMi) is vulnerable to a local
privilege escalation due to flaws in Management Central (CVE-2023-40685,
CVE-2023-40686)"[1]

Two more CVE's were assigned as the result of our reports. To clarify[2]:
Management Central service doesn't need to run for exploitation.

[1]
[https://www.ibm.com/support/pages/node/7060686](https://www.ibm.com/support/pages/node/7060686)  
[2]
[https://archive.midrange.com/midrange-l/202310/msg00345.html](https://archive.midrange.com/midrange-l/202310/msg00345.html)

CVE-2023-40686.description: Management Central as part of IBM i 7.2, 7.3, 7.4, and 7.5 Navigator contains a local privilege escalation vulnerability.  A malicious actor with command line access to the operating system can exploit this vulnerability to elevate privileges to gain component access to the operating system.  IBM X-Force ID:  264114.
